Nine months after a catastrophic earthquake leveled much of Port-au-Prince, hundreds of thousands of Haitians still remain homeless, rubble still litters many neighborhoods, and now the country is grappling with its first cholera outbreak in decades, centered of the coastal city of Saint-Marc, 40 miles north of the capital.
We're asking those of you who have been to Haiti recently to call us and tell us: Have you seen progress?
Email talk@npr.org.
Dominic's(ph) on the line, calling from St. Louis.
And look what that's done in the last year.
The guy inherited enormous budget deficits, skyrocketing unfunded pension liabilities, an economy in crisis, a massive loss of public trust in the governor's office.
He didn't complain.
My dad used to say, never complain and never explain.
Pat didn't.
He got to work.
During a later debate, Republican State Senator Bill Brady offered a different description of his opponent.
Last month we lost - two months we lost 26,000 jobs.
Governor Quinn's the job governor all right, but it just happens to be for Indiana, Missouri, Kentucky and other states.
New Jersey Governor Chris Christie came to town to stump for Brady.
Christie's a darling among conservatives after reckoning with a budget deficit nearly as large as Illinois'.
I'm not coming here saying, hey look what I did in New Jersey, you should do the same thing.
I come here because I believe the direction he is saying he wants to take Illinois in is compatible with the direction I'm taking New Jersey in.
The state's ravaged economy, though, has been the focus of this race.
Republicans are pouring millions of dollars in Midwestern states like Illinois, where Democrats are vulnerable.
Roosevelt University political science Professor Paul Green says Illinois is particularly attractive.
It's Obama's state.
You always want to go plant your flag in the other guy's state.
Governors wield enormous power shaping policy as they try to reduce deficits and balance budgets.
And then there's redistricting, says Bradley University political scientist William Hall.
In almost every state, the governor is an important part of the reapportionment process, which will be upcoming in 2011.
But two weeks before Election Day, the candidates in the Illinois race for governor apparently still have some convincing to do.
A recent poll shows 22 percent of voters haven't made up their minds.
I'm still undecided.
That's Linda Moran eating lunch in downtown Chicago.

And the focus for some potential voters in this very Democratic city is on the mayor's race to come early next year, which explains why Brandon Martini(ph) thought only about a mayoral candidate when asked about his choice for governor.
I know that Rahm Emanuel is running.
I'm not a big Rahm Emanuel fan.
Mayor, oh, governor, geez.
No, I haven't.
I'll probably vote Democrat, though.
Cheryl Corley, NPR News, Chicago.
If you want to know what's happening with the economy, you could do worse than to chat with a realtor.
So we're calling brokers in different parts of the country.
We begin with John Paul Rosser, who does deals in Miami.
Last year, he surprised us by saying the mortgage crisis had not stopped condo construction.
At one point I counted 75 cranes in the sky.
After that I lost count before I could finish.
That was last year.
We've asked Rosser to tell us what he sees in Miami today.
Well, you still have construction going on, but probably the number of cranes are less than half of that, and maybe even only a quarter of that.
Some of the cranes have come down because the buildings are finished, and I think some have come down because the money's run out.
I'm not sure.
Are there half-finished buildings around Miami?
I wouldn't say half finished.
They usually seal the outside, so you really can't tell.
You know, they'll put the windows in and secure it from the elements.

And are the people who were building these condos, or in other cases, I suppose, office towers and that sort of thing, are they able to fill those buildings now that they're getting finished, the ones that do get finished?
No, not at all.

I've read that there's upwards of 50,000 condos on the market for sale, and just two days ago in the Daily Business Review here, they were noting that a young University of Miami law student rented a penthouse in one of these buildings for only $2,400, the 42nd floor.
Good time to rent.
Well, yes, and why would you buy and have a, you know, 5,000, 6,000 a month payment when you can rent the same condominium for $2,400 a month?
Do you believe there are 50,000 people who want a place to live in Miami?
There's people that want places to live, but not at these prices.

Now, I did have an interesting thing happen here, a gentleman that owns nine condominiums on the Miami River, and he got them for about 25 cents on the dollar from what the developer was asking, and only about 40 cents on the dollar from what they were selling at last November, and what's interesting is I think he's got them for less than what it would cost to build them.
